I've been to many, many counts of various sorts. In the room as a 
scrutiniser and this guy will be doing of the following:
- Batching up spoilt ballots that have already passed approval as spoilt.
- Batching up a pile of envelopes that are postal votes by the looks of 
things and writing on how many of them there are. Every count does this 
with the leftovers from batching in 50s or 100s. This is standard procedure 
and not part of the count.
- He's doing the above with actual ballots so that they can be easily 
stacked in a counting tray but this last batch will have a piece of paper 
on top with the number of spares he's counted so checkers can easily look 
at the tray and say 50,100,150,...etc and how many is written on the top 
batch? 27? ok so the total is la di da.

completely remote from the counting desks.

+Deadeye012011 Professor Robertson's report resulted in widespread interest 
on social media.  The research, which covered the period from September 
2012 to September 2013, took in over 600 hours of early evening TV news 
coverage, broadcast by the BBC and STV.  The results revealed the No 
campaign benefited by a ratio of 3:2.

According to the report, the simple numerical preponderance of 
anti-independence statements over pro-independence statements on Reporting 
Scotland and STV News, was clear.

The study revealed:

Reporting Scotland broadcast 272 news items deemed favourable to the No 
campaign against only 171 favourable to Yes.  STV was only marginally less 
biased with the 255 for No and 172 for Yes.
Statements which made use of academic, scientific or 'independent' evidence 
favoured the No campaign by 22 to 4 on BBC Scotland and by 20 to 7 on STV.
Personalising independence arguments as being the wishes of Alex Salmond 
appeared 35 times on BBC and 34 times on ITV with no such personalisation 
of any of the No campaign's arguments.
Broadcasts containing language that was considered insulting to 
independence campaigners occurred on 18 times on both BBC Scotland and STV 
but language interpreted as insulting to pro-Union campaigners appeared 
only 3 times on each broadcaster’s news reports.
Finishing a broadcast item with anti-independence claims which were 
unchallenged happened 28 times on BBC Scotland and 34 times on STV whilst 
ending items with unchallenged pro-independence claims occurred only 8 
times and 17 times respectively.

He was not a vote counter he was a verification supervisor. His job was to 
prepare ballot papers in stacks, whose number is decided by the returning 
officer in charge of the count, ready for counting by the counters. Each 
batch has to have attached a verification form signed or initialed by the 
verification supervisor before being given to a counting clerk. They are 
distinguished by wearing hi vis yellow vests or jackets and their desks are 
completely remote from the counting desks.

Ignorance of process is no excuse for the disgraceful accusations flying 
around here. Stupidity is a reason but still not an excuse.﻿

So they have a big pile of ballot papers, they count them up and write down 
the number of ballots in each wad and the name of the counter of the 
ballots, then they are placed on a table either YES or NO, someone else 
comes along, goes to each table and adds up the votes on each docket having 
no idea whether all the votes have accurately been allocated to the correct 
table because the assumption is that no one can screw up anything this 
simple.

It's not just an absentee vote form, is it?
In Australia, whenever we vote, we have to go to specific, local, polling 
stations. If we manage to get to one of those polling stations, then we're 
given our voting paper(s) & go to a little booth to make our vote choice on 
the paper. From there we fold the voting slip and place it into the 
appropriate polling box.
If we go to a polling station that's not in our precinct, we have to see a 
different person for an "absentee vote". We're given the same voting 
slip(s), but we also have to fill out and sign an affidavit saying we're 
absentee voting and have not voted anywhere else. The polling person has to 
sign as witness the voter's signature and identification and sign the same 
piece of paper the voter did. Then, the whole lot gets sealed into an 
envelope and placed in an absentee vote box, behind the desks.
Obviously, I don't know how voting works in Scotland, but this short video 
sure does look exactly how it is whenever I've done an absentee vote, here 
in Australia.﻿

From my own experience the ballot table where the voters are issued a 
ballot is manned by two to three people.  There is only one here and i 
suggest he is a presiding officer.  Three of their duty's are to provide an 
ongoing tally of how many ballot papers have been issued at three times on 
the say.  To record any spoiled votes because it does happen that people 
will fill in their ballot wrong and return to the ballot issuing table and 
request another ballot.  Lastly there are several forms that need to be 
filled in and returned with the ballot boxes at the end of the day.  Some 
of these can be filled on an ongoing basis during the day and then bagged

1.  Most independent polls indicated before any vote was cast (which could

rigging. 

2. Realistic fears of holes in budgets, so inevitable service cuts, job

profits from North Sea oil (according to even the Scottish boss of the 
North Sea oil).  Anyone who could do maths could work out hi figures were 
inaccurate (and shows rigging on Salmond's behalf if anything).

businesses were going to ignore a chance of milk and honey, like he said 
they'd get?  Any smart business makes their own analysis, they don't just 
accept the words o figures of others, whether Unionist or 
Nationalist.  Independent figures put the profit from North Sea oil last 
year at only half the total Scottish spending on the NHS, so there were 
serious and realistic concerns over how independent Scotland would fund 
their services. 

3. £17 billion extra immediately wiped off the stock market last week, when 
all that existed was a solitary poll putting 'yes' vote ahead.  How do you 
think Westminster managed to fake a £17 billion drop on the markets?  
Objective Scots then realised further that the majority of the world were 
probably right: the economy would indeed crash in the event of 
independence. 

4.  People becoming worried about Nationalists accusing Unionists of 
bullying, when the SNP are actually bullying (e.g. such as threatening 
businesses who are rightfully fearful for their existence - in an economy 
few around the world have any faith in - with a 'day of reckoning' for 
speaking out).  Making formal complaints when journalists ask difficult 
questions, even though the 'no' campaign has not resorted to such bullying 
tactics regardless of what Salmond has accused them of, often on zero 
evidence. 

5.  People realising the SNP often sound delusional, and don't realise they 
are sounding delusional (or they wouldn't be saying what the say 
publically)  So few businesses would want to stick around in a country 
where the ruling government cannot see the holes in their approach  (e.g. 
delusional thoughts that banks (wanting to go south) are 'bullying' them, 
despite that position being reasonable for the banks.  For 
example, RBS's total debts are 12 times Scotland's entire GDP, so only 
the Bank of England could underwrite that.  For banks who cannot guarantee 
their debts collapse, as nobody wants to risk investing with them.  They 
couldn't stay in Scotland if they even wanted). 

6.  Realistically, there would be no credit union - it wasn't just bluffing 
and bullying.  Cameron would have no choice but to refuse a credit union 
with a close general election coming up next year, because the majority of 
the UK public were against it, according to independent polls.  That isn't 
because we want to lord it over Scotland.  This was because we could see 
the realistic risk of the Scottish economy crashing, and the pound being 
dragged down, and the Bank of England in a currency union having to bail 
Scotland out.  Which would far exceed the £5 billion in annual loan 
repayments Scotland threatened not to pay if they weren't allowed a 
currency union. 

7.  No diplomacy skills in the SNP, despite an independent Scotland needing

Ballots are counted up to 3 times, they are batch counted and tallied, then 
sent to another table to be recounted and tallied, if the two tallies don't 
match they are counted again. its highly unlikely that the ballots in the 
wrong pile would go unnoticed on the second count. For this type of rigging 
it would require the rigged pile to be given to another rigger, since this 
would be next to impossible to pull off you would probably require every 
person counting to be corrupt.  Since counters are generally just civil 
servants (from all walks of life both 'yes' and 'no' voters) it is even 
more unlikely that so many 'mistakes' in the first counts would not be 
encountered and reported by a 'yes' voting counter......The result is a 
shame in my opinion but just accept it people....﻿

Hey! I worked at the count and am as disappointed as anyone at the result 
but THIS IS NOT VOTE RIGGING! He has to write the number of ballots on a 
piece of paper that gets added to the top of each batch and sign his name 
next to the count figure. Somebody else has to count the same batch again 
and verify his figure. Every single unused ballot paper is also counted and 
all the totals cross-referenced with each other to make sure every single 
vote is accounted for. We spent 2 hours re-counting because there was 1 
vote missing from our batch of votes. IT IS IMPOSSIBLE for him to do what 
you're suggesting. There are too many checks and balances built into the 
system. Please look for other explanations for the result other than vote 
rigging - it's insulting and demeaning to us all.﻿
